awd_titl_txt: CIF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Quickest Change Detection Techniques with Signal Processing Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The problem of detecting changes in stochastic systems, often referred to as sequential change detection or quickest change detection, arises in various branches of science and engineering. In all these applications, an anomaly in the environment changes in some way the distribution of the sequentially acquired observations. The goal is to detect the change and raise an alarm as soon as possible, so that any necessary action can be taken in time, while controlling the rate of false alarms below an acceptable level. While the quickest change detection problem has been actively studied since early 1950s, there are many open challenges in this field that are of theoretical as well as practical interest. 

This research addresses long-standing open problems in quickest change detection, as well as challenging problems that are motivated by modern applications, such as the following: 1) Optimum quickest change detection for Markov data; 2) Optimum quickest detection for transient changes; 3) (Asymptotically) optimum quickest change detection schemes for multistream data when changes are sparse; 4) Joint quickest change detection and isolation (localization of the change) in multistream data; 5) Controlled sensing for quickest change detection and isolation with composite post change hypothesis; 6) Data-driven quickest outlier detection and isolation. Furthermore, the investigators study the applications of their results in the following areas: 1) Line outage detection in power systems; 2) Epidemic detection; 3) Change detection in financial applications; 4) Surveillance using sensor networks; 5) Dynamic spectrum sensing; 6) Intrusion detection in power grids/networks; 6) Anomaly and fraud detection in big data.

por.por_cntn:
This research conducted in this project was focused on sequential/quickest change detection, problems, including those motivated by modern applications. 

A number of new research results were obtained on the following theoretical topics: (i) Multichannel sequential and quickest change detection, (ii) Joint sequential change detection and isolation, (iii) Optimum quickest change detection for Markov data, (iv) Quickest change detection with transient dynamics, (v) Semi-parametric and universal approaches to quickest change detection, (vi) Efficient detection of sparse mixtures, (vii) Change acceleration and detection, (viii) Subspace sequential change-detection, (ix) Sequential multiple testing with generalized error control, (x) Sequential anomaly detection with observation control, (xi) Change detection in Hidden Markov Models, (xii) Bandwidth-efficient decentralized sequential change detection. In addition, the following applications of the sequential/quickest change detection methods were explored: (a) Statistical power system line outage detection, (b) Epidemic detection, (c) Remote monitoring of patient activity, (d) Surveillance using sensor networks, and (e) Dynamic spectrum sensing. 

PIs Fellouris and Veeravalli collaborated on topics (iv), (ix) and (x), PIs Fellouris and Moustakides collaborated on topics (ii) and (xii), PIs Moustakides and Veeravalli collaborated on topics (vi), (xi), and (d), and all three PIs collaborated on topics (i), and (ix).

Educational activities have included: (i) Invited presentations by the PIs at various engineering and statistics conferences including, IEEE international Conference on Acoustics, Speech, & Signal Processing (ICASSP), IEEE Conference on Decision and Control (CDC), Workshop on Information Theory and Applications (ITA), International Workshop on Applied Probability (IWAP), International Workshop on Sequential Methodologies (IWSM), Conference on Stochastic Processes and Applications (SPA), and Asilomar Conference on Signals, Systems, and Computers, and Allerton Conference on Communication Control and Computing; (ii) Invited seminars and colloquia at various universities including, Cornell, Princeton, Georgia Tech, Rice, Wharton School of U Penn, Rutgers, and Ecole Normale Superieure (ENS) Paris; (iii) Development of  two new graduate courses at UIUC, “STAT 578: Topics in Sequential Detection” and “STAT 578: Topics in Sequential Design”, which were taught in the Fall Semesters of 2019 and 2020, respectively; (iv) Incorporation of developed techniques and ideas in existing courses on Detection and Estimation, Statistical Signal Processing, Probability and Measure,  and Machine Learning at UIUC and Rutgers University.

This project contributed to the extensive training of seven graduate students and one postdoctoral fellow participating in the research at the University of Illinois.  The graduate students in this project were trained in the state-of-the-art of sequential analysis, stochastic simulation techniques, sequential detection, quickest change detection methods and applications. They developed novel statistical methods and engineering tools, and they established strong mathematical results in the course of working on this project.
